Isobutanol synthesis from syngas over K–Cu/ZrO2–La2O3(x) catalysts: Effect of La-loading Yingquan Wu a b Hongjuan Xie a Shaopeng Tian a b Noritatsu Tsubaki c Yizhuo Han a Yisheng Tan a ⁎ a State Key Laboratory of Coal Conversion, Institute of Coal Chemistry, Chinese Academy of Sciences, Taiyuan, Shanxi 030001, China State Key Laboratory of Coal Conversion, Institute of Coal Chemistry, Chinese Academy of Sciences Taiyuan Shanxi 030001 China b University of the Chinese Academy of Sciences, Beijing 100039, China University of the Chinese Academy of Sciences Beijing 100039 China c Department of Applied Chemistry, University of Toyama, Toyama 930-8555, Japan Department of Applied Chemistry, University of Toyama Toyama 930-8555 Japan ⁎ Corresponding author. Tel.: +86 351 4044287. Graphical abstract A series of K–Cu/ZrO2 catalysts with different La loadings for isobutanol synthesis from CO hydrogenation were prepared by a co-precipitation method. The catalysts were characterized by XRD, reactive N2O adsorption, XPS, H2-TPR, in situ IR and Raman techniques, and then tested for isobutanol synthesis from CO hydrogenation at the conditions of 360°C, 10.0MPa, GHSV=3000h−1 and H2/CO=2.5. These characterization results showed that incorporation of La into the K/Cu–Zr catalyst resulted in increase of BET surface area and dispersion of catalyst particles. Especially, medium La addition facilitated the synergistic effect between Cu–Zr interactions, improved the reducibility of catalyst and increased the amounts of dispersed copper. An enrichment of C1 intermediates on catalyst surface related to high dispersed CuO is better for chain growth. In the isobutanol synthesis reaction, the conversion of CO and selectivity of isobutanol increased first and then decreased as the increase of La concentration. Among these La-promoted K/Cu–Zr catalysts, the 3% La/Cu/Zr catalyst exhibited the highest alcohol selectivity of 32.8wt%, which can be radically attributed to the highest Cu surface area. Keywords CO hydrogenation Isobutanol K–Cu/ZrO2 catalyst La2O3 1 Introduction Syngas chemistry is now considered as the main way of natural gas upgrading, and alcohol synthesis from syngas looks especially attractive. C1–C5 alcohols could be used as fuels, fuel additives for octane or cetane enhancement and oxygenate fuel additives for environmental reasons [1]. Isobutanol, one product of the alcohol generation, is an important organic chemical material that would be the raw material of pharmaceutical and chemical products, e.g. anti-oxygen, paint solvent, flavoring agent, plasticizer, and synthetic rubber. Isobutanol is also widely used as an extracting solvent for the purification of strontium, barium and lithium salts. Furthermore, the isobutanol has been approved as gasoline additives by U.S. Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) in 2010 [2]. Therefore, the rapid increase of raw isobutanol consumption requires a low cost manufacturing approach. Generally, most isobutanol is produced by the carbonylation of propylene which is an inefficient synthesis approach with high cost. So, a new synthesis approach is needed and will be reported in this paper. Two types of catalysts are currently used for the synthesis of isobutanol from coal-based syngas, namely modified methanol synthesis catalysts [3–6] and ZrO2 catalysts modified by alkali, Mn, Zn or Pd [7–12]. Various alcohols are produced by the modified methanol synthesis catalysts, but some alcohols, e.g. ethanol, propanol, would have high selectivity that makes them be seperated from each other difficultly. Beretta et al. [4,5] reported lots of secondary chemicals of alcohol, ketone and aldehyde but not linear alcohol. Although ZrO2 catalysts have high selectivity for the synthesis of methanol and isobutanol during this process, the selectivity to isobutanol is only 10% [8]. Meanwhile, the reaction conditions also were severe, such as high temperature (>400°C) and/or high pressure (>10MPa). Zirconia-supported copper exhibits high activity for the synthesis of methanol from either CO/H2 or CO2/H2 [13–15]. Recent studies of the mechanism of methanol synthesis and decomposition over zirconia-containing copper catalysts have revealed that the zirconia is an active component of the catalyst [16–20]. In the case of CO2 hydrogenation, CO2 adsorbs on the zirconia to form bicarbonates species, which undergo hydrogenation to produce formate, methylenebisoxy, and finally methoxide species [18]. The hydrogen required for the progressive hydrogenation of the zirconia-bound carbonaceous species is provided by spillover of H atoms produced by the dissociative adsorption of H2 on Cu. In the catalytic reaction, Cu would mainly provide dissociative H2 and non-dissociated CO to ZrO2 where the alcohol is generated [19]. On this account, it is reasonable to draw a conclusion that introduction of Cu to ZrO2 catalysts is highly advantageous for CO/CO2 hydrogenation. This gives a guideline for the design of high effective catalysts for isobutanol synthesis from hydrogenation of CO. La2O3 was introduced as a promoter of structure [21] and activity [22]. Haddad et al. [23] found that La interacted with the Co metal on Co/SiO2 catalysts, resulting in the enhancement of reducibility of the cobalt oxide, while Adachi et al. [24] reported that La addition could promote the activity of Co/SiO2 catalysts by the agglomeration of cobalt. Park et al. [25] found that a strong interaction developed between Ni species and the support with the addition of La2O3 leading to a higher CH4 conversion. Wu [26] found that addition of La2O3 could stabilize the structure and improve the activity of Cu/ZrO2 catalyst for methanol synthesis from CO/H2. The purpose of the present work is to study the promotional effects of La2O3 in the synthesis of isobutanol from syngas over K–Cu/ZrO2 catalysts. 2 Experimental 2.1 Catalyst preparation The K–Cu/ZrO2 catalysts with different La loadings were prepared by co-precipitation of a solution (1mol/L) of Cu(NO3)2·3H2O, ZrO(NO3)2·2H2O and La(NO3)3·6H2O with KOH (1mol/L) at 60°C, pH=11, in a well-stirred thermo stated container. The precipitate was settled at room temperature for 3h, then washed to pH=7 with deionized water. After drying at 120°C for 12h, the precursor was calcined at 450°C. Calcined catalyst was powdered and impregnated with 2wt% K as a promoter by KOH with incipient wetness method, then it was dried at 120°C for 12h and calcined at 450°C. Finally, the promoted catalyst was pressed and broken in 30–40 mesh. In this paper, the undoped Cu/ZrO2 catalyst is denoted as CZ, and the La doped Cu/ZrO2 catalysts are denominated as x% LCZ, where “x%” is the mass percentage of La relative to the total amount of catalyst. 2.2 Catalyst characterization The X-ray powder diffraction (XRD) patterns of the prepared catalysts were obtained by a Bruker D8 powder diffractometer equipped with Ni mono-chromator and Cu Kα (40kV, 100mA) radiation. The BET surface area was measured by Tristar 3000 Micromeritics instrument. Temperature-programmed reduction (TPR) measurements were performed in a continuous-flow apparatus fed with a 10% H2/Ar mixture flowing at 30ml/min and heated at a rate of 5K/min. One hundred milligram sample was treated at 300°C in pure Argon flow for 2h, then cool down to 50°C. The Argon was replaced and stabilized by the reductive gas. The effluent gas was analyzed by a thermal conductivity detector (TCD). The XPS spectrum was measured by Vg Escalab MK-2 spectrophotometer with a monochromatic Al Kα (1486.6eV) source and the accelerating voltage of 12.5kV as well as power of 250W. The sample was pressed into the fixed sample holder (10mm diameter and 1mm thick wafer), then it was transferred to a high vacuum chamber for further analysis with the vacuum pressure 2×10−8 Pa C1s=284.6eV. Raman scattering (RS) was conducted by the LABRAM-HR800 Raman spectroscopy with an argon ion laser (514.4nm) source. In the same TPR apparatus described above, N2O titration was used to determine the surface area of dispersed metallic copper (Cu0). The Cu/ZrO2 samples were reduced up to 300°C and after that cooled to 30°C and exposed to 1% N2O/Ar (30ml/min) for 10min. A second H2-TPR by increasing the temperature up to 400°C at a rate of 10°C/min under 5% H2/Ar was acquired. The hydrogen consumption was used to calculate the amount of oxygen deposited after N2O titration. A total of 1.46×1019 Cu atoms/m2 and a stoichiometry of 2Cu/H2 were used [27]. The Cu0 surface area was calculated on the basis of the following relationship in: SA Cu = 6.4955 × 10 − 2 × C × D where C is Cu content (%) and D is Cu dispersion (%). The in situ FT-IR spectra were recorded with a Bruker Tensor 27 with a MCT detector in the 4000–600cm−1 range, with a resolution of 4cm−1 and 64 acquisition scans. The catalyst powder (>40 mesh) was put in an in situ IR cell equipped with KBr windows. Before adsorption, the catalyst in the IR cell was reduced at 350°C for 2h with pure H2. Then the cell was heated to 360°C and Ar was introduced for 30min. CO (15ml/min) was introduced into the cell for 30min at atmospheric pressure. The catalyst itself was used as the background of the spectra. 2.3 Catalyst evaluation The catalytic reactions were carried out by using a fixed-bed reactor made of stainless steel with 5ml catalysts. The flow rate of feed gas was controlled by a mass flow controller, and the exit gas was measured by a wet test meter. The catalyst was reduced according to the designed temperature program, i.e. from room temperature to 360°C, by using a mixture of H2/N2 =10/90 for over 2h. The reactions were run by using a feed gas with H2 and CO (1:2.5) at a space velocity of 3000h−1. The reactions were implemented at 360°C, 10MPa. The product stream was analyzed by using a GC 4000 gas chromatograph. Syngas and exit gas were analyzed by using a column of carbon sieves and a thermal conductivity detector TCD regarding H2, CH4, CO and CO2. CH x mixtures were analyzed by a column of GDX-403 and a flame ionization detector. Water and methanol were detected by a column of GDX-401 and a thermal conductivity detector. The mixtures of alcohol products were analyzed by another GC-7A with a Chromosorb 101 column and a flame ionization detector. 3 Results 3.1 The textural and structural properties of catalyst The XRD patterns of K–Cu/ZrO2 catalysts with different La loadings calcined at 450°C are shown in Fig. 1 . The K–Cu/ZrO2 catalyst without La displays a pattern which possesses a broad peak centered at ∼31° attributed to amorphous zirconia [28]. The weaken diffraction peaks at 2θ of 35.6° and 38.8° are ascribed to CuO phase. With the increase in the content of La dopant, the intensity of diffraction peak for CuO weakened gradually, while the peak width broadened slightly. This indicates that the crystallization degree of CuO, as well as the particle sizes of CuO crystallites though it cannot be determined accurately with the Scherrer equation since the CuO XRD reflection is weak, decrease with increasing the La loading. The characteristic X-ray diffraction peaks for tetragonal zirconia (t-ZrO2, 2θ =30.4°) can be detected on the undoped Cu/ZrO2 sample. With the introduction of La, the diffraction peaks of t-ZrO2 become weak and broad. When the content of La dopant excesses 1%, the zirconia exists mainly in amorphous form. Similar results were reported by Chuah et al. [29] and Guo et al. [30], who found that the doping of La was unfavorable for the crystallization of ZrO2 and the growth of ZrO2 crystallite. As shown in Fig. 1, no diffraction peaks of La2O3 crystallites can be found for all the studied samples, suggesting the formation of finely dispersed La2O3 on the surface of catalyst, or the formation of La2O3 non-crystalline compound, which could not be detected by XRD technique due to the low degree of crystallization [31]. When the content of La dopant is 5%, weaken diffraction peaks of t-ZrO2 and CuO appear again. The results indicate that particles of CuO and ZrO2 increase with excess La doping. Real content of La is listed in Table 1 which was detected by ICP. We can see that the real content of La is very close to the nominal content, indicating that components of catalyst were well precipitated during the preparation process. The BET specific surface area (S BET) is listed in Table 1. The BET surface area of the CuZrO2 catalyst is 81.79m2/g. The addition of La causes greatly increase of the surface area (81.79–107.20m2/g). This result indicates that the interaction between Cu and Zr occurs. But a marked decrease in S BET appears on 5% LCZ (65.65m2/g). This result is in accordance with the results regarding the crystallite size, as determined from XRD. The metallic copper surface area (S Cu), which was determined by N2O titration, is also presented in Table 1. It can be seen that the S Cu increased first and then decreased with the increase in La loading. A maximum of 13.8m2/g was obtained over 3% LCZ. 3.2 XPS analysis To obtain some information on the catalyst surface and electrical interaction between copper species and ZrO2 support, XPS analysis has been carried out. The XPS patterns of Cu 2p and Zr 3d regions of the catalysts were shown in Fig. 2 . The binding energies (BE) of Cu 2p3/2 and Zr 3d5/2 core electrons are summarized in Table 2 . The binding energy of Cu 2p3/2 peak is around 933eV with shakeup satellites (940–945eV), and this is used as characteristic for the presence of Cu2+ [32]. The Zr 3d5/2 locates at 182eV which is in good agreement with the reported data of Zr4+ [33]. The BE of Cu 2p3/2 shifts slightly from 933.7 to 933.4eV with 1% La addition. No more obvious changes happen in the range of 1–5% La on the BE of Cu 2p3/2. The BE of Zr 3d5/2 shifts slightly from 181.7 to 181.4eV as the La content increases from zero to 5%. The results, variations on both Cu 2p3/2 and Zr 3d5/2 with La addition, indicate the existence of an interaction between ZrO2 and CuO. Surface compositions of the catalysts determined with the XPS method are listed in Table 2. Compared with the nominal compositions, the surface of catalyst is considerably depleted of Zr. In contrast, an enrichment of Cu on the surface is observed. Moreover, the Cu/Zr ratios are also included in Table 2. Clearly, the Cu/Zr ratios are much higher than the nominal ratio of Cu/Zr (0.24), and a maximum of 0.36 is obtained as the content of La loading reach 3%. 3.3 H2-TPR analysis In order to assess the reduction behavior of the catalysts, TPR measurements were performed. Fig. 3 shows the H2-TPR profiles of the studied samples. TPR of CZ shows a broad intensive heterogeneous peak ranging from 155 to 288°C with a maximum at 208°C. During the catalysts with La addition, all of them exhibit two reduction peaks between 130 and 288°C. As well documented, the low temperature is attributed to the reduction of highly dispersed CuO surface species, whereas the peak appearing at higher temperature is related to the reduction of the bulk-like CuO [34,35]. Since the highly dispersed CuO species are considered to contribute mainly to catalytic activity [35], the relative contributions of peak to the H2-TPR pattern are summarized in Table 3 . In addition, the peak positions are also listed in Table 3. It can be seen that, with the addition of La, the fractions of low temperature peak increase from 0 of the La-free Cu/ZrO2 to 27% of 3% LCZ. Further increase in La loading results in a decrease in the fractions of low temperature peak. These results show that the CuO of the 3% LCZ catalyst is well dispersed, in good agreement with the high Cu dispersion of the 3% LCZ catalyst reported in Table 1. On the other hand, as shown in Table 3, the positions of low temperature peak shift to lower temperatures with the increase in La loadings. Similar change of high temperature peak position can also be observed. It can be seen that the lowest reduction temperature occurs on 3% LCZ catalyst, which is indicative of strongest interaction between CuO and ZrO2. Moreover, it should be noted that La2O3 and ZrO2 cannot be reduced within the experimental region [36]. 3.4 Raman analysis Raman spectra of the catalysts were obtained as shown in Fig. 4 . For all the ZrO2-based catalysts, a broad band centered at 610cm−1 can be observed, indicating the appearance of amorphous zirconia. This point is in good agreement with XRD results. By careful observation, Cu/ZrO2 sample shows a weak hump at 200–400cm−1 owing to the presence of small CuO crystallites and t-ZrO2 crystallites [37], which could be detected by XRD. After addition of La, peaks due to the small CuO and ZrO2 crystallites weaken gradually and nearly disappear over 1% of La loading, relating to the high dispersion of CuO. Intensity of peak attributed to amorphous ZrO2 over 1% LCZ catalyst increase substantially compared with Cu/ZrO2 without La doping, indicating that t-ZrO2 convert to amorphous ZrO2 after La addition. As La content increases from 1% to 3%, spectra of Raman decreases, indicating that CuO and ZrO2 are well dispersed. More content of La relates to an opposite result. 3.5 In situ IR Fig. 5 shows IR spectra obtained after CO adsorption on reduced K–Cu/ZrO2 catalysts with different La loadings at 360°C. On the catalyst of CZ, the peaks at 2176 and 2113cm−1 are characteristic of gaseous CO. By careful observation, a shoulder perk at the bands of 2078cm−1 is due to linear adsorption of CO on Cu [38,39]. A small amount of CO2 (2340 and 2360cm−1) can be observed, indicating that CO2 species is formed from CO reacting with absorbed oxygen (Os) which exists on the catalyst after the catalyst is reduced. The peaks at 1644 and 1248cm−1 are assigned to bidentate bicarbonate species, b-HCO3 − [40]. With increasing La loadings, the band intensity of 2078cm−1 increases obviously, indicating an increase amount of linear CO adsorption. When La loading is up to 5%, the shoulder peak of 2078cm−1 nearly disappears. It is interesting that adsorption of bridge-bound CO (1926cm−1) appears when La is introduced and the intensity of it reach the maximum over 3% LCZ, then disappears with excess La doping. Intensity of peaks of 1644 and 1248cm−1 also increase with increasing La doping and reach a maximum at 3% LCZ, and then decrease with excess La. The band of 1547cm−1 is related to formate species, and its intensity have similar changing trend with bidentate bicarbonate species. These results above reveal that an enhancement of CO adsorption and C1 species was caused by La addition. 3.6 Catalytic performance Activity and selectivity results for the isobutanol synthesis from CO hydrogenation over the Cu/ZrO2 catalysts with various La loadings are summarized in Table 4 . CO conversion is 54.0% on the CZ catalyst, and increases with addition of La doping. A maximum of CO conversion (62.6%) is obtained on 3% LCZ catalyst, then it decreases with excess La loading. The STY of total alcohols is around 130gL−1 h−1. Among the alcohol products, methanol and isobutanol were the primary products and the total percentage of other alcohols was less than 20%. Addition of La courses an obvious change on the distribution of alcohols. The selectivity of methanol, ethanol and propanol decreases obviously and selectivity of isobutanol increases with increasing content of La. A maximum of selectivity of isobutanol (32.8%) is obtained over 3% LCZ. Meanwhile, selectivity of methanol drops to the lowest (55.9%). The selectivity of isobutanol begins to decrease when the loading of La over 3%. 4 Discussion As depicted in the part of XRD investigation, the degree of crystallinity and the particle sizes of CuO and ZrO2 on the La–Cu/ZrO2 catalysts decline with increasing La loadings. It is well known that La2O3 is generally regarded as an additive of thermal stability and applied for various catalysts [41,42]. During the course of heat treatment, the highly dispersed lanthanum species act as isolation islands restraining the coagulation of catalyst particle and the growth of crystal grain [31,41,43]. Therefore, the crystallization and grain growth of CuO and ZrO2 were suppressed. During the XPS results, The BEs of Cu2p3/2 and Zr 3d5/2 have a slight decrease after La addition. The chemical environment of Cu and Zr components would change with the different La loadings. These clearly indicate that the electron transfer would occur between copper species and amorphous zirconia. The results of Table 2 reveal that La addition leads to an enrichment of Cu on the catalyst surface. When the loading of La is up to 3%, the values of surface Cu reach a maximum. It is in consistent with the copper surface area (S Cu) listed in Table 1. For Cu-based catalysts, the reduction characteristic is primarily related to the dispersion of Cu, though it is also affected by the interaction between CuO and support in some cases [34]. Avgouropoulos et al. [34] and Zhang et al. [35] reported that the smaller the CuO particles, the easier they are reduced. Yu et al. [37] found that dispersed copper oxide species interacting with amorphous ZrO2 (Cu⋯O⋯Zr), which shown lower reduction temperature. As shown in Fig. 3, high dispersed CuO appear with addition of La, and the reduction temperature peaks shift to lower. When the loading of La is up to 3%, reduction peaks shift to the lowest position, then shift to high temperature with more La doping. Thus, the addition of La enhances the dispersion of CuO and the interaction between CuO and ZrO2. As shown in Fig. 4, a broad peak related to amorphous ZrO2 is observed, and weaken peaks of CuO and t-ZrO2 are also detected on the catalyst without La doping. With increasing content of La, these weaken peaks related to CuO and t-ZrO2 disappear and the intensity of the amorphous ZrO2 peak decrease greatly as La up to 3%. Addition of La enhances the dispersion of CuO and ZrO2 and inhibits the formation of t-ZrO2. Besides, the intensity of 3% LCZ reaches the lowest one, indicating that CuO and ZrO2 are well dispersed with La loading of 3%. It is in good agreement with XRD results. Further addition of La courses an opposite result. A number of studies have demonstrated that there are two active centers involved in the catalytic process of CO2/CO hydrogenation over the Cu/ZrO2-based catalysts [44,45]. One is the Cu component, and the other is the so-called “support” ZrO2. The Cu could serves to adsorb H2 and CO, and to provide a source of atomic hydrogen and CO by spillover. The ZrO2 serves to adsorb CO2/CO as bicarbonate or formyl species which then undergo stepwise hydrogenation to methanol. During the HAS (higher alcohol synthesis) from CO hydrogenation on Cu-based catalysts, i.e. CuFe2O4 spinel species promoted the interaction between copper and iron species, which facilitate the reduction of catalyst, thus leaded to the higher yield and selectivity to higher alcohols [46]. Li [47] also found that medium iron addition facilitated the synergistic effect between Cu–Fe and Zn–Fe interactions, improved the reduction of catalyst and increased the amounts of dispersed copper and active sites, obtained high alcohol yield. Based on the XRD, H2-TPR, XPS and Raman results, CuO is well dispersed and enriched on the surface of catalyst under La addition, and strong interaction between of CuO and ZrO2 make the reduction of CuO more easily. During the in situ IR results, addition of La facilitates the amount of CO adsorbed on catalyst surface, especially the linear CO adsorption. Increased Cu surface area is the main reason for increasing CO adsorption. Meanwhile, CuO can provide more adsorbed CO for ZrO2 by spillover. So, strong interaction between CuO and ZrO2 will enhance this reaction. We have seen that amount of C1 intermediates, such as carbonate, formate species, enrich greatly over 3% LCZ catalyst. Bicarbonate and formate species have been proposed as the intermediates for methanol formation [48–50]. Higher alcohols can form directly from methanol, as shown using labeled methanol with syngas over an alkali-promoted Cu-based catalyst [51]. Elliott and Pennella [52] suggested, over a CuO/ZnO/Al2O3 catalyst, on the basis of experimental results in which they used labeled methanol that the precursor for the formation of methanol and ethanol is the same. Xu [53] also found that CC bonds in ethanol form via two pathways, direct reactions of 13CO and direct coupling of 12CH3OH. Meanwhile, further chain growth occurred predominantly by the aldol-type addition of methanol-derived C1 species to ethanol and higher alcohols, which followed the rules of base-catalyzed aldol condensations [54]. Isobutanol was formed from C1 β-addition of CCCOH [55]. So, ethanol and propanol undergo further C1 β-addition reaction based on an enrichment of C1 intermediates. The selectivity of isobutanol increases obviously for the 2-methyl-branched species have terminal behavior [56]. It can be seen that, in Table 4, the selectivity of ethanol and propanol decrease significantly, however that of isobutanol has an obvious increase with La addition. To better disclose the relation among the CO conversion, Cu surface area, selectivity of i-C4, LRP (low reduction peaks and its contributions to the H2-TPR pattern) and La loadings, a plot is also presented. As shown in Fig. 6 , as the content of La increase, CO conversion, Cu surface area, selectivity of i-C4 and LRP change in the same trend. All of them reach the maximum with La loading of 3%. So, the dispersion of CuO on catalyst has significant effect on the synthesis of isobutanol. 5 Conclusions In conclusion, introduction of La promoter in the K-Cu/ZrO2 catalyst has obvious influence on the physicochemical and isobutanol synthesis performances on CO hydrogenation. The introduction of medium concentration of La promoter to the K-Cu/ZrO2 catalyst not only facilitates the dispersion of CuO, but also improves Cu–Zr interaction. The synergistic effect between Cu–Zr improves the reduction of catalyst and increases the amounts of dispersed copper, leading to an enrichment of C1 intermediates after CO adsorption, and then results in the higher selectivity to higher alcohols and catalytic activity of CO hydrogenation. Comparing with the K–Cu/ZrO2 catalyst and other La-modified K–Cu/ZrO2 catalysts, the 3% LCZ catalyst exhibits the best catalytic performances for isobutanol synthesis. The STY of whole alcohol and the selectivity of isobutanol are 136gL−1 h−1 and 32.8wt%, respectively, under identical reaction conditions of 360°C, 10.0MPa, GHSV=3000h−1 and H2/CO=2.5. Conflict of interest The authors declare no competing financial interest. coredata.dc:description: A series of K–Cu/ZrO2 catalysts with different La loadings for isobutanol synthesis from CO hydrogenation were prepared by a co-precipitation method. The catalysts were characterized by XRD, reactive N2O adsorption, XPS, H2-TPR, in situ IR and Raman techniques, and then tested for isobutanol synthesis from CO hydrogenation at the conditions of 360°C, 10.0MPa, GHSV=3000h−1 and H2/CO=2.5. These characterization results showed that incorporation of La into the K/Cu–Zr catalyst resulted in increase of BET surface area and dispersion of catalyst particles. Especially, medium La addition facilitated the synergistic effect between Cu–Zr interactions, improved the reducibility of catalyst and increased the amounts of dispersed copper. An enrichment of C1 intermediates on catalyst surface related to high dispersed CuO is better for chain growth. In the isobutanol synthesis reaction, the conversion of CO and selectivity of isobutanol increased first and then decreased as the increase of La concentration. Among these La-promoted K/Cu–Zr catalysts, the 3% La/Cu/Zr catalyst exhibited the highest alcohol selectivity of 32.8wt%, which can be radically attributed to the highest Cu surface area.
coredata.dc:title: Isobutanol synthesis from syngas over K–Cu/ZrO2–La2O3(x) catalysts: Effect of La-loading
